title: Atomic Heart is 2023's First Major Disappointment. (Review)
author: @zalamael
comment:
Aye, this game has a lot of highs, but a lot of lows too.  I hated the intro, it took WAY too long to wander around the area and see and experience everything, for a first time playthrough.  I was so fucking bored because I just wanted to experience the GAME, not the interactive cinema.

It could have been so much better if the first experience of the game was a training zone, in which you get your mission briefing while getting to play with the guns and other weapons, and also to meet the glove AI that annoys you for the rest of the game.

Instead you are thrust into a playable cutscene where your glove and your character act like a miserable married couple, and while the lore is good (I enjoyed it), it is far too long winded.  

Devs need to remember that a game is a GAME, not an interactive movie.  And the worst part is, when you get to play the game, one of the bots can grab you and snap your neck, because you were never shown the QTE was a thing, you just have to die a few times before you learn.

Atomic Heart is a mish mash of games that came before it, but they just don't gel together in a way that creates a harmonious experience.  

The setting and the atmosphere, and the animations of the bots, are the only parts I liked.  Everything else just put me off.  Glad I didn't buy it, but I might do for $10 in a sale.

author: @edgarector
comment:
Completely agree. 
This game needs a real hard mode ASAP. It's insultingly easy even on Armageddon difficulty. You think polymer + ice is overpowered? Just get mass telekinesis and upgrade it to have slam. That's it, you are set for the rest of the entire game. Everything else is to spice up the completely boring, unchallenging and monotonous combat. For the bosses, just use telekinesis + the alternative fire on the morning star (the one that fires its disks away) + an elemental canister the boss is weak against. Voila, you melt it in 2 minutes. Not to mention, you have so much items at your disposal at any given time, you can stock up on them for an even easier time.
They really dropped the ball in terms of difficulty and actual satisfaction from getting through actual tough encounters. And, yeah, the world feels unique and carefully crafted...in the beginning, until you start seeing the same couple of assets over and over again.
You know, there's another older "Russian Bioshock" game called "Singularity". It also has a magic glove with plasmid-like abilities and it's 10 times better: more action packed, way more challenging. Give it a go!

title: Atomic Heart is 2023's First Major Disappointment. (Review)
author: @mod5370
comment:
The game was a let down. I think it was best to not have ANY expectations coming into this game. It was my mistake for thinking this game was going to be open world bioshock and it would be great. It wasn’t. The open world sucked and combat was repetitive. 

The game starts off hot but gets worse the further you get. You die more from getting stuck in a corner than from the enemies. The boss fights were slow and boring. The movement is too limited ( No Sprint ). And I understand there needs to be balance and sprint might be OP but you can add a stamina bar that gives you limited sprint and make the enemies more aggressive so you can’t get away easy. The devs should’ve figured it out.

I beat the game on Armageddon (Hardest difficulty) and didn’t find it to be difficult. I died 7 times total and it was mostly because I got stuck. Never died to a boss. It was a very forgiving experience. The enemies/bosses would let me double dash away and heal/reload my gun and as long as I had heals, I wasn’t able to die. 

This game for me was a lesson of “having high expectations all the time means you will get disappointed more often” and I was reminded that after I completed the game. Thank god for game pass.

title: Atomic Heart is 2023's First Major Disappointment. (Review)
author: @FelixTsang
comment: I didn’t find most of the complaints in this video bother me. FOV slider can be fixed by dragging a file into the paks folder. Sticking can be fixed by smashing movement, jump and dash to unstuck just like every other game. The game runs smoothly for such a graphically good game. The protagonist isn’t designed good but he isn’t designed badly. The dialogue is supposed to show the character’s personality and you’re missing out the story. I find combat fun as movement is not bad as you mentioned in your video. You can Dodge every attack as a reward for good reflexes. The whole point of combat is learning the enemies and yourself to exploit them. You do need to find a specific resource when you want for example thermal scope on your AK. There’s three difficulty option in the release version: journalists, easy and normal. This isn’t a competitive multiplayer game. You don’t need to equip the most op abilities. It’s up to the players preference. Shield and melee is fun with the remote double blade.

While other studios come out with a perfect game on their first try, I think that a lot of the QoL issues that you mentioned in the beginning of the review are probably a result of relatively inexperienced devs not considering certain factors. I think because of how visually impressive the game is and how close to a Triple A title this looks and feels, it is easy to forget that this is still an Indie Game, and that they don't have the same level of experience as Triple A studios in giving their games accessibility options.

Regarding your issues with the main character, English isn't their first language (I think), and probably not the language that the game was written in, and so it's likely that a lot of the awkwardness and the narcissism of the protag might be holdovers from the original Russian that didn't translate as well.

TL;DR: Cut them a bit of slack since it is a project by an inexperienced studio that doesn't speak English as their first language. While it's possible for them to do better, I think that with a few tweaks the game can be improved significantly

Real quick thing I want to add, I am aware and appreciate that Mayo is very honest and straightforward with his opinions and states his experiences and frustrations exactly as they happened. It is very admirable to have that level of honesty, especially in a medium like reviewing art. The goal of this comment was just to perhaps bring something to Mayo's attention that he may not have considered.
